summary: Imprisoned on the other side of the universe, the mighty Thor finds himself in a deadly gladiatorial contest that pits him against the Hulk, his former ally and fellow Avenger. Thor's quest for survival leads him in a race against time to prevent the all-powerful Hela from destroying his home world and the Asgardian civilization.

Thor: Ragnarok - A Hilarious Take on the Superhero Genre

Greetings once again from the author. The question that filmmakers face time and time again: how to make the latest comic book movie standout amidst the plethora of others? The answer comes from director Taika Waititi and co-writers Eric Pearson, Craig Kyle and Christopher Yost, who have created a hilarious screwball superhero action film that not only features the requisite alien war scenes, but also a villain with an unprecedented level of camp that may go down as one of the greatest of all time.

For those who prefer their superheroes to be brooding and dark, this film may be a surprise. Jeff Goldblum steals the show as the Grandmaster, one of the most polite villains we have seen in recent years, who appears to have stepped out of the 1960s "Batman" series. Chris Hemsworth returns as Thor, displaying his impressive comic timing in addition to his Thunder God biceps. The love-hate relationship between Thor and his brother Loki (Tom Hiddleston) is in full force, as is the Bruce Banner and The Hulk (Mark Ruffalo) banter. It is more reminiscent of GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY than the previous Avengers movies.

However, the true standout performance is from Cate Blanchett as the fearsome (yet campy) Goddess of Death, Hela, who is Thor and Loki's long-lost sister and Odin's (Anthony Hopkins) daughter. With an impressive headdress that puts everyone at the Kentucky Derby to shame, Hela is so powerful that she can easily shatter Thor's mighty hammer, reminding everyone that big sisters are known for breaking younger brothers' toys.

As the title suggests, the story revolves around the possible destruction of Asgard. The film features Idris Elba as Heimdall, Tessa Thompson as the one-liner master Valkyrie, Karl Urban as Skurge - who has a great exit scene, and Ray Stevenson as Volstagg, as well as the voice of director Waititi as the rocky alien Korg. Fans of the series will also be delighted to see familiar faces appearing periodically, including a magical sequence that teaches Loki a quick lesson.

Along with the main storyline, there are many nods and tributes to previous versions (such as Planet Hulk and Fantastic Four), as well as a hilarious early stage play featuring three cameos that guarantee big laughs. It is also great fun to spot the reunions from other projects such as Star Trek, JURASSIC Park, and Westworld.

Special credit goes to director Taika Waititi for taking the comic book film world in a new, comedic direction. He is known for his work on comedies like HUNT FOR THE WILDERPEOPLE (one of my favorites from 2016), WHAT WE DO IN THE SHADOWS, and the brilliant but short-lived "Flight of the Conchords." Despite this change in tone, the film is still very much a Marvel movie, with the recognizable marks of Stan Lee, Larry Lieber, and Jack Kirby present throughout. It is also a thrilling adventure film that sets the stage for next year's AVENGERS: INFINITY WAR, with the best use ever of Led Zeppelin's "Immigrant Song." Get ready to rock, roll, and have a great time in a film that offers as much fun as one can have in a movie theater.

Thor: Ragnarok is a fun and action-packed addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. With director Taika Waititi at the helm, the film takes a comedic turn while still delivering impressive visuals and a compelling story. The cast, led by Chris Hemsworth as Thor, is excellent, with standout performances from Tessa Thompson as Valkyrie and Jeff Goldblum as the Grandmaster. The soundtrack, featuring the likes of Led Zeppelin, is also a highlight. While the film may not delve as deeply into character development as some of the other MCU entries, it's a highly entertaining ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Overall, Thor: Ragnarok is a must-see for Marvel fans and anyone looking for a thrilling and hilarious action movie.

Thor: Ragnarok is easily my favorite Thor movie! The movie's humor is very good, with every joke landing every time I watch it. As with all the Thor movies, I really like the dynamic between Thor and Loki, and this movie is no exception. By the end, Loki has fully redeemed himself after years of fighting Thor and its really great to see those two finally fully working together. Hela is an absolutely outstanding villain. Her sheer ruthlessness and power give her an imposing presence throughout the film and her destroying Mjolnir early on makes her seem all the more dangerous and gives the film much higher stakes. The new additions to the cast in Valkyrie and Korg are great as well, providing the movie with an all around excellent cast, rounded out with the Hulk, making for a fun team with great group dynamics that keeps the movie entertaining throughout.

A decent Marvel movie, however, the change of theme and the lack of several previously main characters makes this movie by far the weakest of the first three Thor films. This taken into account, I'd still recommend it for people who are decently invested in the MCU or those who wish to pass the time.

"Thor: Ragnarok" is a visually stunning, action-packed sci-fi movie that brings a fresh and humorous approach to the Thor franchise. Chris Hemsworth delivers a standout performance as Thor, elevating the character with his comedic timing and charming presence. The film's supporting cast, including Mark Ruffalo, Tom Hiddleston, and Tessa Thompson, also adds to the film's overall appeal.

The film's direction, by Taika Waititi, is top-notch, with a visual style that is both vibrant and imaginative. The film's use of color and futuristic landscapes is breathtaking, making "Thor: Ragnarok" a feast for the eyes. The film's music, composed by Mark Mothersbaugh, perfectly complements the action on screen, adding an extra layer of excitement to the film's many set pieces.

However, some fans of the Thor franchise may be disappointed by the film's departure from the more traditional Asgardian themes present in previous Thor movies. The film's plot also lacks the depth and complexity found in some of the Marvel Cinematic Universe's other entries, instead opting for a more lighthearted and comedic tone.

Overall, "Thor: Ragnarok" is a thrilling and entertaining sci-fi movie that sets a new bar for the Thor franchise. Its visual style, talented cast, and comedic approach make it a must-see for fans of the genre and the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Thor Ragnarok takes a hard turn from the first two Thor movies. It is amazing the number of actors who return to play their roles, and this is a principle accomplishment of the MCU series. 

This time though, the Shakespearean mantle is removed by director Waititi, with the weighty, dark scenes from Thor 1 and 2 only referred to in the beginning of the film when Thor witnesses a play being performed before Odin. Throughout the movie, the film is poking fun at Thor, the MCU, comic books and the comic book movie genre. 

This humor is appreciated, and I had a lot of fun watching it the first time. Upon a second viewing, the plot started to creak a bit. There is not a lot of logic used, the hulk doesn't connect with the anger he is supposed to maintain to stay 'hulked out' the whole time. The combat seems to have no rules or danger, until it suddenly does.

But focusing on the plot holes only gets in the way of having a good time, which was the obvious aim with this film. I enjoyed it, it's a good romp, but not much challenge for the mind to think about. Other films in the MCU do a better job addressing something meaningful, even if for just a moment. But this film is fun and bright.
Overall, Thor Ragnarok was colorful, engaging, fun, surprising, & just a solid addition to the Thor franchise. Worth 4 stars within the first half hour.

For 2017:
5 years old already and this is still the best ‚ÄòThor' film and another one of the most fun entries in the Marvel Cinematic Universe 
Thor in the other films has always been a C-list character and someone who could easily fade into the background 
He does have a tragic backstory with his brother feeling betrayed realizing he wasn't Asgardian, losing his mother to the Dark Elves, and most recently breaking up with Jane Foster 
Now the filmmakers make fun of past entries while also subverting expectations, it's almost like they're dissecting the first two films while starting over 
Last we left Thor he saw a vision giving him an idea of the existence of the Infinity Stones and how his power could evolve beyond control 
He's surprised to find that Loki is alive after supposedly dying from his wounds in ‚ÄòThor: The Dark World' and that Odin had been kicked out of Asgard onto Earth 
Odin then dies after seeing both his sons one last time and with that a sister they never knew about, Hela the Goddess of Death played by Cate Blanchett escapes from her prison 
Thor and Loki are no match for her and she plans on returning to Asgard to take back the throne she felt was stolen from her (she points out she's the real weapon Odin had to conquer the stars but later gave it up to be benevolent)
But first Thor and Loki have to escape Sakkar which is made up of garbage ruled by The Grandmaster played by Jeff Goldblum who oversees gladiator matches for entertainment and profit 
Thor even runs into a former warrior of his home called Valkyrie played by Tessa Thompson who's abandoned her warrior virtue since she and her soldiers couldn't defeat Hela long ago 
Being imprisoned with other fighters he runs into a rock-skinned creature called Korg voiced by Waititi himself 
Not only that but Thor comes across Bruce Banner/Hulk after he disappeared when they both last encountered Ultron, this is a new side to the Hulk we haven't seen as he's not too monstrous in nature and has been living the lord of luxury as a champion fighter for Grandmaster 
The funny thing is the people on Sakkar actually glorify the Hulk in these matches praising the violence even though Banner doesn't want to be that which in itself is very modern 
Most importantly though Thor has to prevent a prophecy from coming true called Ragnarok in which all of Asgard dies because of him 
Heimdall comes out of exile too to assist in stopping Hela and saving all the Asgardians
Director Taika Waititi who's known for indie comedies brings so much more of a colorful, goofy side to the character than we've seen and he's one of the few Kiwi directors to step into the limelight 
Thor is actually given a personality rather than coming off so heartbroken and burdened by destiny and it's very funny throughout, he knows when to be silly, charming, subtle and serious 
His chemistry with Tom Hiddleston proves both of them have plenty to squeeze out; Thor and Loki butt heads constantly but still end up accomplishing much more 
Can Loki actually be trusted for once even when Thor tries to change him?
Blanchett has some of the best wardrobe and villain designs of any of these MCU movies and it helps her acting backs all of it 
There's also timely themes in here about history being whitewashed, rewriting it to suit our own needs, covering up our pasts to paint a better picture and forget our past transgressions, it's true kings and conquerors are proud to have their accomplishments but ashamed of how they got them, a country or kingdom isn't a place it's a people that make it 
Waititi essentially makes an immigration story and several parallels to Aborigines and also inserting subtle Australian branding throughout 
And the aesthetic of the movie embraces the traditional Jack Kirby artwork from many of the comics giving it a retro 1980's feel like a pop video 
Rather some cool-looking action too that matches many comic frames especially the ending and when in slow-motion looks like beautiful illustrations 
Let's also not forget the many inside references to past MCU films and callbacks 
True this is light on story or might worry viewers that there's so much stuff crammed in and half the jokes end up being a 50/50 ratio but they balance it out figuratively being a psychedelic experience 
Thor is finally given some proper treatment this time around without relying on too much melodrama and this is one of the best films of 2017

"Thor: Ragnarok" is not only Thor's but also Taika Waititi's magnum opus. I never thought I would like this film so much on my... third watch, I guess? It's almost a reboot for Thor. The tone is not dramatic anymore, it's now a declared comedy, and Chris Hemsworth only wins with that. Since the first "Thor", I've been saying that he's a limited actor in the drama aspect, but he is an excellent comedy actor. He managed to put the comedy above the drama, still does well in the non-funny parts, and all without mischaracterizing Thor. Indeed, this is his best performance as the God of Thunder. Anthony Hopkins' participation is beautiful, Tom Hiddleston is still amazing as Loki, Benedict Cumberbatch has a small appearance, and all of the scientist characters are gone, giving place to the ultra-charismatic universe of Sakaar. Jeff Goldblum is funny as the Grand Master, the dynamic between Thor and Hulk is pure entertainment, Taika Waititi voicing a rock man is joyful, and Tessa Thompson is a "Thor girl" (I can't believe I'm using this term) a lot better than Natalie Portman (Valkyrie and Thor don't have a romantic relationship, far from that, but she takes Jane Foster's place as the female co-protagonist). Analysing Cate Blanchett's awarded career, she's one of the last actresses I would cast for the type of villain that she does, but her casting was incredible, not only due to this subversion or to her talent, but also because she incredibly manages to be at the same time threatful and caricature, fitting with the film's tone with perfection. And I can't believe I'm saying that about a film directed by Taika Waititi, a man who never convinced me, and the dramatic moments in his movies were constantly swallowed by the comedy ones. He found the perfect balance here, and I could not be happier. One of the best MCU feature productions.

"Thor: Ragnarok" feels like a breath of fresh air to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. The film boasts a clever script filled with witty humor that will keep audiences engaged and entertained from start to finish. The movie's visuals are also a feast for the eyes, with director Taika Waititi delivering a visually stunning spectacle that's both colorful and inventive. The cast is fantastic, with Cate Blanchett delivering a standout performance as Hela. Overall, "Thor: Ragnarok" is a fun and energetic film that revitalized the Thor franchise!

I really liked this film, found it highly entertaining even though I didn't love the Ragnarok story with Hela itself. Honestly, this movie is all about the Marvel humor, which is turned up to 11 in this film, but it works. I enjoyed this film as a self deprecating superhero based action/adventure (Marvel) film. Its about what you'd expect - a decent cast (including, I was surprised to find, Anthony Hopkins - can't say I expected him to be in a Marvel film but there you go. He plays Thors dad, so I guess I saw him in the previous Thor films but I haven't seen those in some time, so I must have forgotten that), great special (visual) effects and lots of action. I've enjoyed the Thor films before because of the characters humour, I suppose a bit like Deadpool only less rude (lol). There is an element of fourth wall present I think. I like films like this that don't entirely take themselves seriously and if your looking for an entertaining watch that you can switch off and enjoy for the CGI, then yes, I'd certainly recommend this film. At times it reminded me of the Tron films.

There are some less exciting scenes I suppose but its good to have some lengthier dialogue at times for the character development. I suppose its a little long and some may feel it to  be too over the top but its mostly a bit of fun that I quite enjoyed, so I'm giving it a high-ish rate - suffice to say, if Marvel type superhero films are your thing then this will be for you but no doubt, if that's the case, your already quite familiar with it. Oh and also, one final thing - keep watching even when the credits start appearing.

This movie is the "can I copy your homework? - Yes but don't make it too obvious" of the first Thor movie. But where the first movie was an excellent establishing of characters, kickstarting them on what seemed like a very exciting path, this one's only aim seem to destroy everything. And I mean EVERYTHING, metaphorically and materially. It's saturated with corny jokes. It's main humor is degrading every single character. Speaking of them, they're all one-dimensional caricatures. This movie undoes any and all development they went through, re-establishing the idea of a bully leader and subdued servants, with Thor as the bully and everyone else as his goons, be they aware of it or not. It took the original narcissistic family dynamic and instead of further breaking away from it put Thor as the narcissist, Valkyrie, Heimdall and that opprobrium Korg thing as the enablers, and once again put Loki as the scapegoat who needs to stomp himself down to receive a scrap of love. This was disgusting to watch, especially because it's hailed as a "fuck colonialism" type of movie and then had Odin, THE colonialist, be praised and hailed. Seriously, fuck this shit, and fuck the shit its director and main actor love to say in interview against Bruce Banner, Loki and their fans and the fans of the previous movies. A movie about a bully, made by bullies.

1) Would I pay to see the movie again? (Answer = Yes)

Next to Endgame, Thor Ragnarok is the black sheep of my marvel opinions. Even when this movie first came out, and everyone was calling it  one of the best Marvel movies, I always had to speak my mind and say, "No. It's not".
Don't get me wrong, I do like the movie! The performances are all good, the visuals are gorgeous, the action is awesome, the music is fantastic, and the great majority of the comedy really does work!
But where I draw the line, apart from the dodgy effects, just ok villains, and rushed pacing, is the tone. While the jokes worked, they often took away from the more dramatic/heavier moments of the film.
Again, when all is said and done, I do enjoy the movie and it is extraordinarily fun! But, for my money‚Äòs worth, I would've preferred it if this movie balanced comedy and drama better than it did.

Obviously, this is a beloved film in the MCU. I can't deny that, and it's not bad but it's far from great. As far as acting and production quality is concerned it's on par with the best of the MCU. The problem is the writing and the interpretation of the character. The writing is just flat out lazy for a large part of it. There are wasted scenes executed with extreme mediocrity, such as the death of Odin. There are entire action sequences that are just "yadda, yadda, yadda" level phoned in. Hela takes over Asgard in...maybe three minutes? Let's not even pretend there is real character development. Characters are broken until..."well, it's time for them to not be so..." It's some of the worst writing yet in the MCU. Still though, if you've never read a Thor comic, and you don't care about quality of story, it will pass the time. I can't give it a negative score, but maybe it's worst to have a neutral one? I know a lot of people praise this, and to be honest I think I know why. Taika Waititi. He's such a great director that everyone wants him to succeed regardless of how bad the quality of story telling is in the case of this film. I love Waititi, but it's sad that THIS is the film most people praise him for, and not his better films with less spectical but better writing.

Taika Waititi gives a much-needed makeover to the God of Thunder and crew

Check out the full review at: https://neoncamerareviews.blogspot.com/2022/01/thor-ragnarok-2017.html?m=1

So we find out that Thor has an elder sister who is the goddess of death and wishes to kill them all if they do not bow down to her. Hella, the hidden sister, is played well by Cate Blanchett.
 Ragnarok, or end of days, is referred to in this movie as the end of days for Asgard. Of course, Loki, the trickster is alive, making his tearful death in the previous film now irrelevant. 
And we find Hulk, now on Planet Sakaar hailed to all as the Grand Champion. And the Grand Master is none other than Jeff Goldblum. 
The only gripe would be with the Valkyrie ‚Äì an actress of color portraying a Norse character. To put it into perspective, in this current day and age, Norway has less than 2% who are African heritage. So back in the days of yore, the only men and women were white and mostly blonde. How does a black woman attain such an honour? I would really not mind if it had been an actress of acclaim or someone with better acting skills or even someone with a better back story than "I was almost killed by Hella once so now I commit treason by turning my back on my duty and show young girls it's okay to be stupid drunk all the time, so much in fact that I pass out". After all, Heimdall was portrayed by Idris Elba who, in my opinion is a class actor, so much that I don't mind a race-swap in James Bond if he plays it. Idris Elba clearly became a fan favorite for not just myself but a whole lot of others. Yet this actress who plays the Valkyrie has no prior street-cred to her name and it remains to be seen if she will become popular with the MCU among fans. Also along lines of diversity, I read that they were trying to make this character bisexual ‚Äì something that didn't show up in the film and thankfully so. 
Then we have the great Anthony Hopkins who reprises his role as Odin, perhaps for the last time. That definitely adds a touch of class. And Karl Urban does a great job as Skurge, and to see him who is a survivor, choose to right path even when he knows it will lead to his doom, is sublime. 
Of course, if you thought that the actors in the Thor/Loki play in the beginning of the movie look familiar, then you are quite right. Matt Damon and Luke Hemsworth have cameo roles as Loki and Thor play actors. Yup, Stan Lee also has a role as always, happy to re-design Thor's hairstyle. 
The movie completely destroys what we now know of Asgard, there is no Odin, no Thor Hammer, no Rainbow Bridge and no Asgard. While the paradigm shift is drastic, its repercussions will only be felt in the later movies of the MCU. 
All in all, a pretty good movie even though it seems to add a feeling of finality to the rich background of Thor, namely Asgard, his family and Asgardian comrades and friends. It isn't without its issue though as the movie feels like two entirely different films were pieced together, which does lead to some strange tone shifts at times, and both storylines are interesting with the Asguard storyline seeming to suffer due to time constraints. Overall Thor Ragnarok is a very important movie and explains where Hulk and Thor were during the events of Captain America Civil War. I highly recommend going back and watching this movie again, but it can probably be skipped if doing only the essentials of rewatching the Marvel Cinematic Universe in preparation for Endgame.

Thor: Ragnarok is a franchise saver and redeemer after its two predecessors. Seconds in the movie already has a completely different feel from the two that came before it, and this difference is a huge breath of fresh air and makes the movie far more enjoyable than the two that came before it. Hemsworth is at the peak of his comedy, Loki has a great character arc, Hulk is a welcome face and Korg and the Grandmaster are scene-stealers. Hela is a far more powerful, intimidating and convincing villain than Malekith was, and she's a formidable foe to our heroes. Ragnarok perfectly balances comedy with sadness and seriousness and goes a great job of not squandering it's A-list lead and supporting cast as it gives every substantial character moments to shine. There are a few nice callbacks to previous MCU installments, but the thing about this movie that stands out is how entertaining it is considering that the stakes are decently high. Ragnarok is a movie that wants to have as much fun as possible considering its premise, and it succeeds in doing so in every regard. It delivers in every way that fans would want for a third installment, but it also fundamentally changes the Thor franchise and takes both it and the character in new directions that they badly needed. The mid-credits scene nicely and smoothly ties the movie back into the bigger universe and timeline with disrupting the flow of the movie. Thor: Ragnarok is a must-see for fans of the characters and viewers looking for some good entertainment and a lot of laughs.

After the release of Infinity War, I had begun bingewatching all the MCU movies. And I'm not gonna lie to you. I wasn't feeling like watching this movie. After seeing Thor and Thor: The Dark World, I had taken the assumption that Thor movies are always bleak and lifeless. They always try to be serious when they can't possibly do it when they have characters like Thor, Loki and Odin. And so when it was time for me to watch this movie I was very reluctant, because I knew I can't skip it. But I'm glad I sat through this movie, because it was a huge improvement.

The movie started out in Asgard, from the point where Thor: The Dark World left (and honestly the only thing I remember about that movie). The way that movie had ended, I had thought this movie would build more on Loki pretending to be Odin. But that ended immediately. Instead this movie focuses on Thor and Loki's estranged sister Hela, who had been abandoned by Odin at a young age. She easily manages to defeat both Thor and Loki and sends them to exile on Sakaar, with Thor reaching the planet two weeks after Loki. That was the part where the movie skyrockets the interest. I like everything about it movie from a cinematic point of view - the CGI, the acting, the comic timings, the story, the dialogues. Everything is absolutely perfect. I could undoubtedly say that this is one of, if not the best superhero movies which is not an origin story but rather a continuation of events. The comedy of the arc is the selling point. My favourite dialogue was the rock guy saying, "I planned to start a revolution but didn't publish enough pamphlets so hardly anyone turned up."

After Thor, Loki, Hulk and Valkyrie come back to Asgard to stop Hela we get the best CGI ever witnessed with Thor. I really like how his eyes glow whenever he has to shoot lightning. I always wanted him to be like that. Thor really had a very drastic character development. I know many people have said this - he lost his father, learnt about his sister, his friends were killed, his precious hair was cut by none other than Stan Lee himself, he continuously got taken down by Valkyrie and lost against Hulk, his entrie planet got blown up and his people encountered Thanos in space. And yet this was the funniest MCU movie yet. And not just Thor, every scene that had Loki in it was always interesting too.

However, this movie was obviously not without its set of flaws. For starters the elephant in the room, the amount of exposition that was given throughout the movie was too much, with most of it never being mentioned any time afterwards. There was even a scene where Thor is explained everything about Sakaar on a virtual trip, but it was never talked about afterwards nor was it necessary. If it wasn't for this unnecessary padding of runtime, I'd have given it 5/5. The Planet Hulk arc was also quite unexplored from the comics, and it would have been great if they made a spinoff movie on Hulk also since Hulk has never been given a solo movie starring Mark Ruffalo. Then the biggest plot hole, Valkyrie electrocuting Thor also didn't make sense since Thor is literally the God of Thunder and he shoots lightning from his hands. And then when Hela pins Thor he gets the ex-machina of his father telling him about his superpowers.

Thor: Ragnarok is an excellent MCU movie. It's kinda sad that this can't be enjoyed unless you've watched Thor: The Dark World and Avengers: Age of Ultron. Because it could have really been cool to show to someone who has no idea what the MCU is all about. It does have the good reward to it, since you can watch Avengers: Infinity War after it. And the tone of this movie is so flexible that even the grim Infinity War completely suits in being its sequel.

THOR: RAGNAROK was an enjoyable bit of mind candy. The Marvel movie was more comedy than action-thriller, although there was plenty of that too. Chris Hemsworth, Cate Blanchett, Tom Hiddleston, Idris Elba, Anthony Hopkins, Tessa Thompson, & Mark Ruffalo certainly played their parts to the hilt with their tongues firmly in-cheek. The story of an unknown sibling arriving to cause chaos is not old, but the setting made for an over-the-top family squabble. Lots of explosions & sword play followed. Jeff Goldblum, Karl Urban, & Benedict Cumberbatch added to the luster of the cast and fun as well. It was certainly a popcorn movie, so sit back and enjoy the action.

I absolutely loathed this film! It deserves no stars. All the male stars are turned into himbos, with the exception of Elba and Asano. 

Chris Hemsworth‚Äòs comedy here is indistinguishable from his MIB film, or Ghostbusters characters. It's that bland and horrific, you could literally interchange the characters and it wouldn't effect the film. 

I realize that the second film, Thor the Dark World was a mess, but this was worse because it was intentional. It deconstructed the hero's journey the first Thor film put the character on. It gave the character no growth, but regressed him and those around them simply to make fin of them. Where as the first movie was situational comedy, this one was making fun of the characters by making them imbeciles. 

Hemsworth has been on a comedy kick ever since his Ghostbusters role. It's not that he hadn't done comedic roles prior to it, but it created a bug in him. He insisted on doing more comedies, but kept doing the same chAracter in each of those new comedies, and the movies suffered for them. He's a talented actor, who is capable Of doing comedy, but he's gone off the rails recently with the type of comedy and the directors he's worked with. 

Taika Waititi I'm not a fan of, and this is a piece of work that never should've come to pass. As I've said it's cheap laughs at the characters expense that deconstructs all the progress the characters had previously made. And the mixed mythological elements such as toga wearing Asgardians makes me wonder if he's that ignorant of the mythology? Or that uncreative as a comedic director. 

The writers Kyle and Yost I usually enjoy, but here I despised them. Where the first movie relied on situational comedy, a man out of his element or time; this film made Thor and the majority of the male characters stupid. Other marvel films used comedy to great effect, but the characters were never the butt of the joke, not even when Captain America became America's ass. 

See it if you want, if you like it good for you, as for me I'm looking to hire Lacuna Inc To erase my memory of ever having watched this pos.

Thor has never been the easiest character to integrate in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. In a world dominated by the science and reason of Tony Stark and Bruce Banner, we now had to jump into a land of trolls, giants and Gods. The contrast seemed hard to digest, but the makers of the first THOR movie had the brilliant idea to adhere to Arthur C. Clarke's third law: ''Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic''. Hence, Asgard is not as much a realm of Gods, but a race of aliens that have been mistaken for Gods in their early Earthly visits.  Something also pretty much right out of the pages of Erich Von Daniken's CHARIOTS OF THE GODS. A brilliant move.

Kenneth Branagh  was a logical choice in many ways to direct that first installment, as his familiarity with Shakespearean prose made him a natural in this throne room family drama between the wise King Odin, the tempestuous unworthy son Thor and his devious half brother Loki.The film had its weaknesses (including a rather obvious set for the surprisingly small town where a lot of the action takes place), but Australian Chris Hemsworth's considerable charm shone through and made for a sympathetic God of Thunder and an instant star. Add a magnificent score by Branagh regular Patrick Doyle and you had a potent addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

THOR: THE DARK WORLD was less successful.  A bit glum, and featuring an astonishingly bland performance by Dr. Who alum Christopher Eccleston, the film never rose much above an uninspired plot and direction by Alan Taylor who must have felt overwhelmed by stepping away from his usual TV productions. Not a bad film by any stretch, it still remains a low point in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

This time, Marvel went to Kiwi director Taika Waititi who had demonstrated a great sense of humour in films like the hilarious mockumentary What We Do In The Shadows, and the uproarious Hunt for the Wilderpeople. So one could safely assume that this new adventure of the ''Lord of Thunder'' would also include a healthy dose of comedy. And one would assume rightly. Taking a hint from the wildly popular GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY films, THOR RAGNAROK is an outright comedy from the very first scene where Thor confronts the fiery Surtur, to the very last post credit scene. And the result is a bit of a mixed bag. While it makes the film one of the most enjoyable and gleefully entertaining  Marvel film to date, the humour at times impedes on the proper dramatic impact of certain scenes that have a lot of potential emotional weight to them. There is a cataclysmic event taking place near the end of the feature, for instance, that is almost spoiled by, appropriately enough, director Waititi in his Korg persona. The joke is funny, but takes away from the potency and significance of the scene. 

It's as if Waititi is unable to extract himself from the intrinsically silly nature of comic book lore. Because whether we like it or not, there is something  profoundly ridiculous in stories about flying men, jade skinned brutes and Thunder Gods. That state of mind does serve him well for most of the film, eliciting laughter on many occasions. It also unabashedly refers to previous comedic moments in the previous Marvel films, to great effect. There was already potential for greatness in THE AVENGERS' first pairing of Hulk and Thor, as was hinted in one of 2012's funniest singular moment at the movies. 

The film makes great use of that chemistry, aided by Hemsworth gift for comedic timing and Mark Ruffalo's refined gruntings. The superhero team-up, occurring after Thor's accidental landing on planet Skar where a stranded Hulk has thrived as a gladiator champion under the tutelage of the Grandmaster (a hilarious Jeff Golblum just being Goldblum), is pure comedy Gold.

Meanwhile, back on Asgard, Hela, the Goddess of Death (a formidable Cate Blanchett), who has been freed from the Underworld, is starting to lay waste to the Golden Realm. Hela has captured my imagination ever since I first saw her on a terrific John Buscema cover back in the early 70s.

Hela's considerable power is well manifested in her hostile takeover of Asgard and her destroying Thor's ubiquitous Mjolnir. However, her character never demonstrate one of her most terrifying comic book ability in the film, in what could have been a grisly scene. 

But her character remains truly formidable nonetheless, and a flashback scene showing her confrontation with the fabled protectors of Asgard, the Valkyries, remains one of the most strikingly beautiful scene ever put to film...

Which brings us to another valuable player in the film, Thessa Thompson's Valkyrie, the drunken, disgraced lone survivor of this attack against Hela. Her character is a strong, funny and charismatic addition to the Marvel Universe, and I cannot wait to see her in action again. Her appearance is a striking departure from the comic book origin, but I cannot say that it is a bad thing, for many reasons.

When I first saw the trailers for the film, I was extremely pleased to see Karl Urban as Skurge, in what seemed like a retelling from the character's dramatic final moments from the outstanding Walt Simonson's run of Thor in the eighties. Skurge (AKA the Executioner) had been a longtime Thor villain, who ended up having a change of heart and saved Asgard in an heroic confrontation with a horde of ghastly enemies.

Waititi reprises this famous scene in the film, but the character arc is sadly not as powerful as in the comic book, and while the scene still remains quite strong, it never reaches the emotional, iconic nature of the source material.

The big surprise of the film is Mark Mothersbaugh's score. A bit like Danny Elfman surprised everyone in 1989 with a BATMAN score that strayed miles away from his Oingo Boingo days, Mothersbaugh hits epic orchestral highs with memorable, gorgeous melodies, all the while making numerous musical references to his DEVO origins. A thoroughly enjoyable score with moments of eighties retro electronic bliss. And one cannot talk about the music for this film without mentioning the pitch perfect use of Led Zeppelin's THE IMMIGRANT SONG in two key scenes.

One last note about the design work in the film. I was overjoyed by the obvious Jack Kirby influence in costume and set designs, especially on Planet Skar. Kirby created the comic book version of the Thunder God back in 1962 with Stan Lee (who by the way, as another of his ubiquitous cameo in the film), and it is pure happiness to see the colourful, angular sensitivities of the King of comics applied so beautifully on the giant screen.

Overall, THOR RAGNAROK is a highly enjoyable film, that will never bore the viewer, and makes drastic changes to the Thor mythos that will impact the Marvel Universe in no uncertain ways. If you like the Marvel Cinematic Universe, this will be another must in your collection. If you are tired of Superhero films, the comedic aspects and self deprecating humour may manage to sway you in the right direction again. Some may be weary that the Marvel films are turning into comedies, but trailers for BLACK PANTHER and early words on the next AVENGERS films may lay those fears to rest.

Thor: Ragnarok, directed by Taika Waititi, created this breath of fresh air, being undoubtedly, the best installment to the Thor series. You can tell that Taika had a great respect and bond with the returning cast members, seamlessly working together on this exciting tale. Waititi did an amazing job adapting his multi-genre style into this film, but the fact that he tried to keep it in continuity with the Marvel style, it didn't really fit all that well; If Waititi made this film with strictly his style, it would've paid off better, grasping what made Guardians of the Galaxy a great film.

Even though Waititi played things a little safe, while the premise is overused and predictable, he brilliantly switched up the whole narrative, doing his best to make this an original and entertaining film. Thor: Ragnarok, was so much fun, while really embracing the weirdness the saga poses. The film flows at such a brisk pace, that can be laidback at times, while having so many memorable moments. Waititi created this film to be more of a comedy-based film, but the other darker tones he incorporated worked pretty well, although some of the dramatic scenes were played off a little light.

Thor: Ragnarok stands out so much because of the characters! Sarah Finn did another amazing job casting this huge talent! You can genuinely tell that everyone was having a good time, which translates to great performances across the board! Chris Hemsworth is a stud! He brings so much wit, humor, and heart to the Thor character, being able to create chemistry with anyone! The writers gave him everything he needed to make his character more likable, while giving him some nice character development. We finally get to see Mark Ruffalo back in action as Bruce Banner and The Hulk, and he absolutely steals every scene that he's in! Ruffalo was born to play this character! He brings a tremendous likability to the character, bringing so much wit, and subtle humor, to give his character more great layers! Ruffalo can fit any scheme that he's thrown into, being such an enjoyable presence everytime. Tessa Thompson gets thrown into the MCU mix, and she is another one that fits the scheme like a glove! She is such a fantastic addition to the saga, while putting on such a natural performance, here. Tom Hiddleston returns as Loki, but he doesn't have too much to do in the film, because of his antics in the past. Believe it or not, he is more mellowed out, and grounded this time around, also having some nice character development. One of the most favorable additions to the film, was Korg, voiced by Taika Waititi. He didn't have much to do up until the end of the third act, but he was just an enjoyable presence, having some great jokes along the way! Karl Urban as Skurge, was fine, but he wasn't one of those characters that needed to be there, especially due to the fact that he's just a jerk. Urban definitely made the best out of his screen time, having a few decent moments, but he isn't the most memorable out of the cast. You probably wouldn't expect to see Jeff Goldblum in the MCU, but him as The GrandMaster was awesome! The way his character was written was perfect for the tone of the film! Even though he didn't have a whole lot of screen time, he made the absolute most of it! Cate Blanchett may have overcooked her performance a tad, but she was still great as Hela. She is one of the better villains of the MCU, having a good motive, and connection to Thor and Loki. One of my only issues with Hela, she could've been fleshed out better, instead of throwing a lot of exposition at us. There is a lot to be explored about her character, so it's understandable to an extent, but it left her character to be a little boring, at times.

The screenplay by Craig Kyle, Christopher Yost, and Eric Pearson, had a lot of good pieces of writting, with a great flow and timing, but some of the dramatic aspects were cut a little thin, due to the comedy-heavy genre. The film would've benefited if they would've cut back on the comedy just a little bit, to tighten up the emotional and dramatic aspects; other than that, there isn't much to complain about.

The production of this film was gorgeous! There were so many beautiful colors, with unique world designs. The effects of the film weren't the best it could've been, but it worked a lot better than something like Black Panther. The action of the film was one of the best aspects, being well balanced, well shot, and really entertaining! The score and soundtrack wasn't the orthodox score from the MCU films; Waititi and Mark Mothersbaugh incorporated this rock anthem, and it just worked perfectly!

Overall, Thor: Ragnarok is one of my personal favorite MCU films. Even though this blast of fun comes with issues, Thor: Ragnarok belongs close to the top of your list!

This was my least anticipated Marvel movie of 2017, but it turned to be the absolute best. I, like many others, did not like the Thor franchise at all. Thor was okay, and Thor: The Dark World was atrocious. Thor was not a bad character, but his personality wasn't very interesting, and the movies suffered because of the directors insisting that they needed to go to Earth. To me, it seems like the previous directors of the Thor franchise were trying to make a movie, but created certain guidelines, such as the need for a love interest, a serious and Shakespearean tone, and to go to Earth enough to make it feel more relatable, and not like a cosmic adventure with gods and aliens. But for the third Thor movie, Taika Waititi came in and just asked a simple question: Why? And he scrapped all those elements and made a crazy and hilarious movie. And it worked like a miracle. Taika Waititi was the miracle needed to save the Thor franchise. Thor: Ragnarok is the most hilarious movie in the MCU, but it works. Finally, in this movie, it seemed like Marvel nailed the character of Thor. Thor is supposed to be funny, and he works best when he is. Hela is an amazing badass villain and has clear motivations and poses a serious threat to the heroes. The action is also cool. I loved the Thor vs. Hulk fight and wished it had continued on longer. And the final battle was epic. But despite almost everything being played for laughs, it still succeeded in getting its themes across and made sure not to play those for laughs. All the scenes with Odin were not funny for a reason. The messages of Asgard being a people, and of Thor's power coming from within were amazingly well done. And having Led Zeppelin's Immigrant Song play during the final battle was he best possible combination of story and music. Lightning and Led Zeppelin: a perfect combination. This movie also did the best job showcasing Thor and Loki's complicated relationship. And of course, Thor finally learns that sometimes, people like Loki just can't be trusted. The irony is that this movie actually has the darkest story of all the Thor movies. Thor 1 was about an arrogant god losing his powers and being betrayed by his younger jealous brother. Thor 2 was about some guy trying to destroy the universe for some reason we never get to know. But Thor 3 is actually a political satire, including many elements like propaganda and secrecy, showing that Odin was not a nice and loving person at all. He looted and conquered many worlds and ruled them all for himself. Thor and the Asgardians didn't seem to realize that the gold and luxuries on Asgard were all tainted with blood and slaughter. Every drop of gold was a representation of the lives Odin and Hela took. If one of the previous directors had directed this, it would be a disaster. They would make it dark with many political themes. They would basically try to make it like Captain America: The Winter Soldier, which would be ridiculous, because Thor is not Captain America, they are two completely different characters. But because of the tone of the movie Taika sets, you don't even realize you're watching a satire. This is an amazing movie and truly one of Marvels best.
Thompson stole the show, but unfortunately the strange comedic tone fails to fit the story, which sucked some of the emotional  weight. Still fun but my least favorite of the Thor films.

Despite its adherence to the kooky, sometimes slapstick, sometimes realistic, always offbeat, kiwi humour, Ragnarok is also an out and out true fantasy; much more so than Guardians of the Galaxy with its space opera chops, Ragnarok delivers cloaked exiles trekking refugees across lush landscapes, fights inside trippy rainbow light bridges, posturing enthroned becrowned fire demons, the severed head of a gigantic guardian dragon, prog rock album art cover shots sprinkled liberally throughout and Mark Mothersbaugh's delicious score that flipflops between 80's nostalgia synth and Howard Shore's Lord of the Rings. The lack of distinction between the magic and science mentioned in the first Thor movies finally lives up to the magic side of things; the opening and closing title logos almost as good as the film itself, not to mention the comic-con announcement/trailer typeface, all promising a coin-op arcade cabinet of a film that was eventually, actually, delivered.

Thor: Ragnarok is a good example of liberal canon and yet also, about evolution of character; Thor, a waning, one-note, foppinsh, stiff do-gooder needing to find a new throughline above the macho sycophants and narcicists that rule the Avengers world. As such we're given an impressively short time on Earth and instead given a micro and macro level view of the workings of the planet Sakar, repurposed here from Planet Hulk to give us a greatest hits skim over deeper, more creative comic bokk source material. But the characters are allowed time to bond here; Thor's way of dealing with Banner and Hulk are hilarious and realistic, the idea that The Avengers just end up using each other is touched upon nicely here the film is allowed to explore the only superpowered Avenger who isn't pretending to be someone he's not. He's a hero and he bloody well knows it through and through, he doesn't have to put on a suit because his Dad didn't love him, he doesn't have to fight his darkside through Gamma exposure, he has to convince and rally those to the cause of good, only to discover (see Ragnarok) that it was good for him to do nothing. He can't fight nature, death and rebirth, because it is the universe. It's all these even if it is hidden, which makes a refreshing change.

The film does have a problem with zipping all over the place like a saturday morning cartoon in its effort to (admirably) resolve a bunch of cameos and scenes from previous unrelated Marvel entries, but I suppose it's a refreshing twist to see the entire end credits sequence featuring Doctor Strange played out in full here, it almost feels like the most solid link between disparate films they've crafted yet.

The film veers in to slaptick a little too often but when it is let off the leash to be full badass, my god does it go full badass: Thor actually using his lightning powers to decimate his foes; John Wicking his way through Draugrs and using his hammer to flee dirty great creatures and the clearly videogame-influenced ship battles involving characters jumping from ship to ship to disable them directly. A wholly appropriate smattering of Led Zeppelin got my fist and heart pumping and a smirk on my face that said: "Well done Thor Ragnarok, well played."

But the fact that this film is having so much fun and invites you along to have it too, only makes the misfires all the more bitter: Take Tessa Thompson for example, there's no doubt she was having fun, but her acting style of looking smug and fighting with a truly distracting and hard to understand BRITTOSH(tm) accent, was only the icing on the cake for her character who had no proper catharsis and no moment of a real ending or closure to her story. The fact that she was hired in as the kick-ass female(tm) and not warranted properly and woven in properly cheapened her immensely.

Also missed is all the weight and depth and aching, ponderous beauty from Hulk and co. from Planet Hulk - It wouldn't be hard to shoehorn it in to a later entry, but losing Meek and his history and personality from PH and the relationship between Korg and Hulk in PH were particularly standout in comics and were weak here. I suppose there was the faintest hint of the relationship between Valkyrie and Hulk/Banner but it misses some of the most beautiful and impactful nuances of the romantic relationship of PH.

I also think more time and attention could have been spent on some of the CGI. Because Taika stages the extras and physicasl backgrounds so well, Asgard has never felt so real unlike most of the other Marvels that suffered from acute greenscreenitis. The CGI background work and sets are generally excellent which means sore thumb sequences such as CGI Hela fighting off the hoardes reminded my of Matrix Reloaded's plasticky blandness, and some of Hulk's moments were played far away with emphasis on acting and movement, leaving a lingering desire to want to see a few close ups of Hulk talking to build a stronger sense of connection and to tame my curiosity as to how they made this Hulk tick.

One of the stronger aspects is the strong, almost resolution, to Loki's story. He is the brother in this film and the story deserves him, unlike The Dark World, and it deserves to explore brotherhood in it considering their connection to Hela. Hela is given enough to do, is charismatic enough and has motivation and backstory etc etc but she ends up being mixed bag. Due to the speed and globetrotting nature of the film, she feels like an immovable object, taking 90 minutes to make her way from the rainbow bridge to the warehouse of antique relics. Had she been employed as someone in the way of their journey and not just waiting for them to get back the way Guardians 2 managed to do, it might have not felt like a film of two halves.

Anthony Hopkins is another symptom of the film playing catch up with the decisions of prior titles; he starts strong, but really, he's Loki at that point, and when he's himself he is detached and is glossed right over. The emotional side never plays out properly and the best parts of the film's themes are left unexplored. The colonial idea that Odin paid for the vast beauty of Asgard with his bootheels over the countless other worlds is a fascinating and a surprisingly obvious one. It came out of leftfield, but was not unwelcome and tied directly to the titular Ragnarok, smacking nicely of the Crusades. It was powerful and smart but it left Odin unaccountable as he turned in to gold dust and disappeared, there's not enough running time or clever scripting to have Thor or Loki deal with the fact that their empire and their father dealt in so much bloodshed. Maybe if his parting speech made more sense in retrospect instead of being wishywashy forgettable claptrap.

However. When a film make a conversation about a vampire stake weapon so deftly that I can't breathe through the laughter, or when Thor waxes about how much he loved snakes and how Loki played a prank on him as children that's so funny I think I'm going to die. When cameos are so brazen and stupid they feel like they belong in Anchorman not Marvel's throwaway Avenger, then the film manages to fully and wholly redeem itself.

The films goofy charm is awash with 80's music and glam rock villains and it's no small feat for it to be, for me, the film I wanted Guardians to be when I first watched it. It's the film I like as much as everyone else seemed to like Guardians. Ragnarok isn't as emotional, but I like it more. I liked the Hulk/banner transformation that stirred me, I like that its influences and taste are less crass and more kiwi, and it wasn't the plethora of slapstick humour that kept me laughing alone, it was the conversational, humanising dialogue amidst this alien, fantastical world. And the fantastic array of acting doing its best to make it the most unique entry in to Marvel's machine. And its Taika's little details, the use of Pure Imagination, the destruction of all the hero tropes in to childish, playing-action-man-with-your-mates moments, that prove that a strong director can push past the Marvel factory and yet still play ball enough not to get fired ceremoniously or unceremoniously.

Thor Ragnarok is revered as a comedic masterpiece by critics and audience viewers alike. This stimulating film is great for laughs and for a strange spin on superhero storytelling; with it's brightly colored and chaotic visuals; with it's strange, yet admittedly hilarious dialogue, Thor Ragnarok is the Jeff Goldbloom of marvel movies. If Jeff Goldbloom was accidentally cast into a dark, serious, coming-of-age film.
The acting was on par; Chris Hemsworth (Thor) and Tessa Thompson (Valkyrie) played off each other easily and expertly. Every character added something unique while keeping the shared theme of hilarity and slight absurdity; despite the serious plot of their story.
The film score was created by Mark Mothersbaugh, who is also known for The Lego Movie. He added an electronic/80's synth feel to the movie, fitting well with the bright color scheme and humor. Though not fitting well with the events of the story.
Waititi's comedic style clearly shows through in the form of constant humor with the superhero genre being the butt-end of the jokes. The excessive amount of humor was likely the result of the dialogue being 80% improvised. This film is defined as a comedy. A lot of people complained about this film, because they found the comedy distracting from the plot.
When you do hear praise, you only hear about how they couldn't stop laughing from Goldbloom's oddball humor and Hemsworths' improvisation. What you hear much less about is the quality of the plot itself. No one really cared about the plot because they were too busy laughing. 
Which is a shame, because the plot is quite impactful; It raises the stakes immensely and immediately within the first 20 minutes of the film and keeps them raised. It mirrors Thor's character arc in the first film, but on a new and final level. Thor Ragnarok is a story of loss, strength, and growth. He loses his hammer, his father, his hair, and his pride in the first half, and by the end, he's grown more powerful than ever before. And then Korg butts in with "Oh my god, a hammer pulled you off?"
Frankly, it's a waste of plot.
	Well-placed humor is not only acceptable, but encouraged; but the movie's constant flow of humor was out-of-character, and juxtaposed the feel of the film with the seriousness of the plot; the film's humor essentially breaks the fourth wall at the end of every scene, and frequently, no, incessantly separates the audience members from the plot; it's really quite efficient; and it's not gentle; it's pretty disorienting for the audience to get yanked out of the story and slammed back in over and over again. This is what the great "Thor: Ragnarok" achieved.
Ultimately, the story had a great plot, but no one was able to appreciate it or take it seriously because the character's themselves weren't taking it seriously. Despite all the good things that have been said about this movie, in terms of dialogue vs plot, for anyone who appreciates a good story, Thor Ragnarok is simply a frustrating film.

The comedic value of Thor Ragnarok sets Director Taika Waitit first venture out with the Marvel Universe apart from the rest. Where we would normally be given the geopolitical and social values with a side dose of humor we see these focus points reversed, the end result is a great movie that has to be watched, in the right sequence, with the rest of the movies to understand what is happening when they get to End Game. The story focuses on the sequence of events started when Loki had taken Odin's place on the throne culminating in the end of Asgard, a prophecy foretold as Ragnarok. Cate Blanchette looking like a bad-ass Lilith coming in as Thor's older sister, and rightful heir to the throne, destroying Mjolnir before knocking him out of the bifrost and into a relm controlled by the Grand Master was complete Hollywood, but it worked. By contrast of the gold walled castles in Asgard, with Sicar's "the edge of the known and the unknown" being set with a  strong resemblance to the original Star Wars trash scene the movie made good use of the visual setting; even the 'devils anus' looked like it sounds it should. There are several other examples of visually subtle humor, like Banner waking up from being the hulk for two years with beads around his neck like he had been partying the whole time at Mardi Gras, or Stan Lee making his obligatory cameo as the barber who got to cut Chris Hemsworth's hair. I can only say I am going to miss seeing Stan in future movies; I moved to Alaska the day after my seventh birthday in 1976 and had been given an 11"x 17" Thor Comic as a present but really for the trip, o say that his stories ignited the imagination of millions of kids just like me would be an understatement, he is still doing it to this day in the minds and hearts of whole new generation. The moral message to Thor Ragnarok, that home is where the heart is, would make him proud; the fact it had more a comedic edge than the rest of the movies in the franchise, I think, would have made him proud because at the end of the day it was always about entertaining us- something this movie did on several levels.

Thor: Ragnarok is exactly why Thor is the best part of the cinematic MCU - it's fun (especially with Taika Waititi's obvious influences), action-packed, but also contains some wonderfully layered performances. I love the continued rivalry and rollercoaster brotherhood of Thor and Loki especially. Chris Hemsworth is continually able to be both mourning anger and boyishly cheeky convincingly. I loved Jeff Goldblum basically playing himself - or, at least, his public persona. Cate Blanchett was born to play a queen and she plays an evil one with relish. It's fun to see the Marvel film's interlacing plots star to tighten and it creates even greater tension. Tessa Thompson is a revelation as a lost Valkyrie who starts off saving our hero for profit before remembering her oath to protect the Throne of Asgard. Her swagger and timing are on point. There's also quite a few really fun cameos - especially if you are a fan of Taika's oeuvre. I did miss Natalie Portman as Thor's Jane and I thought some of the visual effects were a little less than we've come to expect from the franchise, but Ragnarok is still some of the best Marvel has to offer.

After two fairly lacklustre Thor films, he finally seems to have found his feet and his mojo in the MCU, the free-play of cast creativity is on full display in this hilarious new take on Thor, we get more character development than we've ever had, the relationship between Thor and Loki really turns a corner, with the latter experiencing something of a redemption arc throughout the course of this film, and the titular hero fully realising his true power and relevance to the people of Asgard, whilst equally setting us up for the behemoth that is Infinity War. Hemsworth and Hiddleston are both on point as ever, Mark Ruffalo excels in his more prominent role, Cate Blanchett is utterly fierce as Hela, giving a stunningly dominant performance as the primary antagonist, and a compelling one at that, even the minor roles stand out, Clancy Brown was booming and domineering as the voice of Surtr, and even in his limited role as Odin, Anthony Hopkins' presence always fills the screen and the scene. One of the big highlights of this film for me is Taika Waititi himself portraying Korg the walking, talking pile of rocks, everything that comes out of his mouth is absolute comedy gold. But on top of all that, everything about the film visually is just fabulous, it's clear that there was a lot of influence from the comics, Sakaar looks every bit like you'd expect a junk planet on the other side of space to look, the colour palate is vibrant and yet doesn't take away from the beaten up nature of the location. All the other locations have distinct feels in terms of their visuals, I especially liked the opening scene with the battle against Surtr, and then the giant dragon. And my god does Mark Mothersbaugh absolutely knock it out of the park with the score, a solid blend of 80s synth rock and traditional orchestration, with additional use of classic rock tracks, Led Zeppelin's "the Immigrant Song" a particular highlight during Thor's two big battle scenes. Kenneth Branagh may have introduced the world to Thor, but Taika Waititi found a winning formula with regards to how to approach films surrounding Marvel's god of thunder, and I am thrilled he was brought back as both director and screenwriter for the fourth Thor film, as the guy is a directorial genius.

"Thor: Ragnarok" is the funniest Thor movie to date. Tessa Thompson, who portrays Valkyrie, gives a stunning performance as a newbie to the MCU. Cate Blanchett's Hela is a pretty impressive villain and honestly one of my favorites. As always, Chris Hemsworth (Thor), Tom Hiddleston (Loki), Idris Elba (Heimdall) & Anthony Hopkins (Odin) gave great performances. I do have to say, though, Jeff Goldblum, who played the role of the Grandmaster on the planet Sakaar, was one of the big highlights of the movie. Goldblum, in general, is a highlight and a great actor. The storyline is nicely planned out and it perfectly ties into "Avengers: Infinity War". If you love Thor, definitely check out this film!

When the first Thor film debuted, audiences believed that these characters were the weak link of the MCU. When the second film hit theaters, audiences again scoffed at the characters and the film, declaring it too dark and brooding for the MCU. Ragnarok has shut those naysayers up. This film allowed for the characters to spread their wings and fly around negativity towards the goal of making a MCU worthy film. Being one of the final threads before Thanos dropped by for Infinity War, this film does a very good job of explaining the absence of Thor and Hulk for Civil War while also giving them both their own arcs outside their comfort zones. I did not like how campy it got, delving too far in humor then it needed to. However, the look, true feel and atmosphere of this film are amazing and truly needs to be experienced. Definitely looking forward to seeing Natalie Portman as a female Thor and how they interpret the stories that she is a part of in the comics.

Ragnarok officially breaks the MCU Villain Curse, as Cate Blanchett injects fresh humor into someone who would be teteering on the edge of cliche if not handled well, and Jeff Goldblum offers even more comic relief to keep audiences laughing. Ultimately, it is the kind of film that makes fans wish Waititi had directed it from the start, and it proves that building a link between films does not have to come at the expense of a great story.

Thor: Ragnarok blends so many fun aspects of the MCU and combines them into one movie. There is the comedy people love, the action people love, the bright color scheme, and then the unique, fun characters. Hemsworth, Hiddleston, and Goldblum are all excellent in this movie. Jeff Goldblum was one of the funniest characters in the MCU thus far. The vibrant colors is what really stands out in this movie. The colors make the movie pop and feel like a comic book ever more. The movie's comedy makes it hilarious and seem like a joke in a way, but the movie carries a lot of meaning as it is the end of Asgard as a place, but not as a people. I loved the addition of Surtur because he is a great villain to put on the screen, but not rely on because he's full CGI. The best thing this movie does is redefine Thor. Thor was a character that seemed to be broken and unfixable in solo films, but Taika Waititi does just that. This is probably the best directing in the MCU that is not the Russo brothers. Waititi really brings a comic book to life and also voices the funniest character in the film, Korg. Really a great film.

This is now the 3rd time I've seen Thor Ragnarok and I can gladly say that I enjoyed it a lot more then the last time I saw it.

Thor Ragnarok is the 17th MCU film and the 3rd Thor film. The film was directed by Taika Waititi who also directed Hunt for the Wilderpeople. The film stars Chris Hemsworth as Thor and Tom Hiddleston as Loki.

The acting in the film is strong for the most part, but I do have to say that a few of the actors didn't really fit their characters.

Like most of the films in the MCU the characters are memorable and some of the best from comic book history, but even though there's characters like Thor  and Loki who I feel are portrayed very well there are a few other characters who let me down personally. One in particular was Jeff Goldblum as the Grandmaster. As a huge comic book fan I felt that they really toned down his power and didn't use him as well as they could've.

The cinematography was steady with a few very good shots of the scenery and characters. One shot I really liked was one toward the beginning involving Mj√É¬∂lnir.

The film also had some very sound and unique settings ranging from Asgard to the planet Sakaar.

The set designs and props like most MCU films were done very well from the building designs to some of the various items within the marvel universe.

Like the set design and props the costume design and makeup is also done very well especially with the characters on Sakaar.

The style I found was okay. The colour scheme and some of the plot points I liked, but I didn't really like some of the other plot points. 

The practical and special effects I felt were just okay. Some times it looked quiet good like with the Hulk, but other times it would look just as bad as when Black Panther was at its worst.

The film did have some strong action here and there especially the final battle.

The score of the film was forgettable, but I have to say that I really liked how they used The Immigrant Song by led zeppelin.

The story though quiet inventive didn't really keep me invested, but at least it worked a lot better then the story from Thor the Dark World. 

The comedy was hard for me because I did find myself laughing, but there was also some jokes that in my opinion fell very flat and just distracted me from the characters.

For most of the film I felt that it had a lack of atmosphere, but luckily the ending had some quiet strong atmosphere.

I also have quiet a lot of complaints with  the film from the Hulk to some nit picks which I consider as spoilers.

The film wasn't boring at any point, but I wouldn't say that I enjoyed it as much as most of the other MCU films.

Over all I give it a
6/10

This movie doesn't feel like a Thor movie. When I think about Ragnarok, it feels to me more like an experience of a sort. The movie does what Iron Man 3 does for Tony but this time for Thor, that is he must learn to be an epic hero without relying on his weapon. It provides a nice explanation of Banners whereabouts while setting up Infinity War. I want to say more about the production of the movie but it really is just a standard Marvel film. The reason it is one of the better films is because it is SO FUNNY. This movie could easily be labeled as a comedy because it is filled to the brink with jokes. Usually this many jokes would make the audience cringe, here however thanks in part to the hilarious supporting cast, EVERY joke lands. Korg, Loki, Doctor Strange, and The Grandmaster all have time to flex their comedic muscles one last time.

'Ragnarok' plays out like an extended SNL skit on an enormous budget, and that's not a bad thing at all. Taika Waititi's oddball comedic sensibilities let Hemsworth finally flex his comedic muscles (is there anything this guy can't do?) while giving the series a much-needed injection of personality and style. 
It's a treat just how bizarrely comedic the third 'Thor' movie is, and the film's many, many gags are endlessly entertaining to watch on top of some very enjoyable action. At the same time, it's somewhat jarring seeing the film played out as a full-on comedy after everything that's come before it, making the darker material involving Cate Blanchett's very meh Hela, goddess of pointy objects, hard to take seriously. It's also a little disappointing seeing the film tease more substantive themes like Asgard's imperialist past and Odin's mistakes only to discard this thematically piquing material as quickly as it's brought up. It leaves you wanting for more.

Thor: Ragnarok has its good moments, but relies WAY too much on humor that doesn't always land. That is not to say that their aren't plenty of great comedic moments, but almost half of the jokes fall flat. Marvel movies are typically very good at balancing humor with darker moments, (first Guardians of the Galaxy, Winter Soldier, Civil War), but sometimes they go overboard with the jokes and they don't always land. The story isn't all that great here either as not all that much happens during the duration of this film. Sure the arena sequence is fun, but it lacks true substance. While the acting is good especially from the likes of Tom Hiddleston and Jeff Goldblum, Ragnarok suffers from a lack of a compelling story and over-reliance on hit or miss humor.

With Thor 1 and 2 being relatively weak movies, who would have expected for Thor 3 to be this good.  With Ragnarok, the Marvel creative team did a 180 turn on the vibe of Thor.  While the first two instalments to the Thor franchise are very serious mythological movies, Thor 3 is a self aware comedy-action film.  Who knew Chris Hemsworth could do comedy?  Cate Blanchett is a great Hela, at times a bit of a comedic villain, but well suited to the vibe of the film, and her action sequences are entertaining and believable.  Of course Jeff Goldblum is also worth mentioning for his fantastic oddball-weirdo portrayal of Grandmaster.  But I suppose the biggest shoutout goes to director Taika Waititi for his wacky vision which breathed new life into the Thor franchise, no longer super serious mythology, just lighthearted fun that pays respect to the source material.

With an air of cocky flippancy from the get go, this third installment in the THOR franchise finally strikes a tone that hits the nail on the head, hammering home the goofiness that always made the character appealing, too often buried by self-serious theatricality in the first two films. The movie even acknowledges those earlier overly dramatic missteps with a clever mock play-within-a-play, poking fun at both their pseudo-Shakespearian leanings and their dull sense of smug pomposity. That shift in tone in turn accompanies a move away from the usual MCU emphasis on inner righteousness---it hardly matters that only one who is "worthy" can wield Mj√É¬∂lnir if there is no hammer whatsoever---replacing that swollen-headed (while retaining the swollen-armed, thankfully) self-importance with self-sacrifice and separation, seeking in the end a new and better beginning. More so than most other entries in the Marvel universe, in true mythic fashion (and bolstered by a fashionable retro 80s aesthetic) Thor must be deprived of various phalli (his hair shorn, his eye gouged out, his hammer smashed) to at last overcome the self and adopt assume his place as leader of the fatherland.

A parody. A spoof movie with some incredible action scenes (especially the one at the beginning), some nice interactions between Thor and Loki, and Thor and The Hulk (inevitably eventually interrupted by forced humor), and a fantastic Cate Blanchett as Hela. 

I honestly cannot believe that people find the God of Thunder throwing a ball at a window and have it bounce back and hit him on the head as something even remotely funny. That goes for the majority of the humor in this movie. After watching both Guardians of The Galaxy movies, you pretty much know what to expect. Absolutely every character is going to talk like a schoolgirl from California, everyone is going to act out of character from one moment to the next, and all expectations will be subverted for comical effect. The best example of this last point being the scene where Banner throws himself out of the flying craft to turn into the Hulk and help out in the fight near the end. Was there anyone watching this that didn't know he wasn't going to turn? That he was going to predictably fall flat on his face. Because this is supposedly funny? When the thing you thought was going to happen doesn't end up happening, and the character ends up in ridicule? I wouldn't mind it being predictable if it was funny, but honestly, it's just dumb. Want to turn a Valkyrie into a short brown girl? Whatever. Just make the character work. Seconds after this character's introduction, when she falls of her own spacecraft drunk off her ass, you know it isn't happening. So forced.

The fact that the movie doesn't even respect the moment of the complete annihilation of the physical kingdom of Asgard, just so the alien that speaks like a British dude can throw in another weak joke in, says everything. This is not a real Marvel characters movie, it's a spoof movie. It's what would come out if you took a serious script and turned it into a 2 hours long worth of Saturday Night Live sketches. There's nothing wrong with this, of course, if it works. But the fact that Marvel chooses to go this route with established heroes and villains, characters we are familiar with (do whatever you want with the Guardians of The Galaxy), shows how little faith they have in this particular Thor franchise. I hope we see less of these type of movies in the future. And if we do, I hope this type of pervasive, forced, dumb humor only infects characters we don't already know and love.
